title: What are some good books about the History of the Philippines, and Filipino culture? - Quora

response.answer_text: Jerome Espinosa basically covers all my personal favorites, but I would recommend another set. In Our Image by Stanley Karnow Anything written by Ambeth Ocampo The Star-Entangled Banner: One Hundred Years of America in the Philippines by Sharon Elmendo Amazon.com: The Star-Entangled Banner: One Hundred Years of America in the Philippines (9780813534114) When I read a history book, I look for cold-hard facts, if the writer shows any bias, I immediately dump the book. For example: “Gregorio Del Pilar heroically defended Tirad Pass until his last breath.” The anecdotes here are completely unnecessary and just trickle it with story-telling. Here is a better way of wording it. “General Del Pilar was tasked to defend Tirad Pass to halt American advance.” No bias there, and informative at that. I would also recommend reading some books about the PH-American war if you want to broaden your horizons on PH-US Relations, just refer to the aforementioned authors.

If one has the time and patience, and loves details, I would consider Blair and Robertson’s s 55-volume work, “The Philippine Islands”, which covers the pre-American period from 1493 to 1898. This can be read online or dowloaded for free. Then you can go to Stanley Karnow, Sharon Elmendo, Ambeth Ocampo, Teodoro Agoncillo, and the other writers of post-Spanish Philippine history. Nick Joaquin is more anectodal than actual history.
